article:
An 'interference fit', also known as a 'press fit' or 'friction
fit', {{cite book
| title = Principles and design of mechanical face seals author = Alan O. Lebeck
| page = 232 publisher = Wiley-Interscience year = 1991 url = http://books.goog-
| le.com/books?id=RnOZ4zl6CRMC&pg=PA232&dq=%22Friction+fit%22+%22interference+f-
| it%22+%22press+fit%22&lr=&ei=8YNkS4L2KJH2NPGp_IsO&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%22Frictio-
| n%20fit%22%20%22interference%20fit%22%20%22press%20fit%22&f=false isbn = 978-0-471-51533-
| 3 }} is a fastening between two parts which is achieved by friction
| after the parts are pushed together, rather than by any other means of
| fastening.

For metal parts in particular, the friction that holds the parts together is
often greatly increased by compression of one part against the other, which
relies on the tensile and compressive strengths of the materials the parts are
made from. Typical examples of interference fits are the press fitting of shafts
into bearings or bearings into their housings and the attachment of watertight
connectors to cables. An interference fit also results when pipe fittings are
assembled and tightened.
